Comment: The Fast Ladder seems to invite an up and at 'em attitude, so it's 1. e4 for me once more.
The Spanish Torture.  Is this wise given my current difficulty in the mini-tournament of that name (P9 W4 L5) (and the other games aren't going too well..)?

I don't often play the Exchange but it makes a change to give it an outing now and then.  When Andrew Martin did a simul at Reading a few years ago, I bought his book on it, though I didn't consult it in this game.

The correct way to recapture.  White can't yet win the e-pawn because Black has a strong counter.  I can't remember what it is, I just know that I mustn't take the pawn yet.
This prepares Rd1 followed by the advance of the d-pawn.  I think this is more dangerous than an immediate d4.

Now White's pawn structure looks a bit more solid.
Black immediately exposes an attack on f3 and creates a threat against e4 and therefore g4.  The threats aren't immediately effective but could soon become so.
White uses his attacked pawns to counter-attack.  This protected passed pawn is a monster!
For the second time, White launches a wing attack, chasing away an unsupported, intrusive bishop.

Now White improves his knight with tempo by threatening to swap it for Black's Bishop.
Black in turn improves the position of his Queen and makes the threat to f3 a real one.
